title: The way we look
intro: How much does appearance really matter? Neil and Alice discuss keeping fit, New Year's resolutions, peacocks, corsets, and the things we do to make us feel good about ourselves.
this_week_question: From a study done in the UK, which physical aspect of their appearance were men most likely to say was their favourite? Was it…
You can hear the right answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: have too much of something nice
a decision you make to do or stop doing something at the beginning of the New Year
parts of the DNA in a cell that control the physical development and behaviour of an animal
a tight-fitting piece of underwear that squeezes you in and makes your waist look smaller
the professional or social position of a person in relation to others

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil… Alice … and I'm Alice. Have you er… gained some weight, Neil? You're not looking in great shape…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I'm afraid so! My New Year's resolution is to get in shape – or to get fit through physical exercise. I look fat, don't I?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well… er… Did you overindulge during the Christmas holidays, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I'm afraid I did, Alice. Overindulge means to have too much of something nice – like all that lovely Christmas food!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, lovely. Why do you think appearance is so important to us, Neil? Getting in shape is a very popular New Year's resolution – that's a decision to do or stop doing something at the beginning of the New Year.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Good question. Well, I think we all judge people according to the way they look.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: The subject of today's show is appearance or the way we look. Did you know Neil that better-looking people tend to be judged by others as more intelligent?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That sounds unfair!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: I know. Well, show us you aren't just a pretty face by getting today's quiz question right. From a study done in the UK, which physical aspect of their appearance were men most likely to say was their favourite? Was it… a) their hair? b) their face? Or c) their height? Neil OK, I'm going for a) hair. I like my hair.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: You have lovely hair, Neil.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: And a lot of it.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Anyway, we'll find out later whether you're right or not. Now, it's not only people who make quick decisions about others based on the way they look. Some animals do this too. Peahens – that's a female peacock - prefer male peacocks with lots of eyespots on their tail.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Why's that?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, one theory is that a male peacock's tail is a sign of his genes. Genes are part of the DNA in a cell that controls the physical development and behaviour of an animal. It takes lots of energy to grow a big tail, and to carry it around, so only the strongest, healthiest males can afford to do this.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So what do men need in order to attract women, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: A deep voice and a square jaw, according to research.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, let's listen now to fashion historian Amber Butchart describing what men used to do to enhance – or improve – their physical appearance.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Amber Butchart, fashion historian and analyst Men quite often would wear corsets throughout [the] 18 th Century even into the 19 th Century. It was possibly concerned with displaying status and rank rather than what we now define as physical attractiveness but I think the two were very bound up together.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: This was Amber Butchart. A corset is a tight-fitting piece of underwear that squeezes you in and makes your waist look smaller.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I didn't know men used to wear corsets! That might make you talk in a high voice – and that wouldn't be very attractive, would it?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, no, Neil. It's a very interesting look and sound for you… On a more serious note, Amber says that men weren't wearing these uncomfortable garments – or clothes – just to look more physically attractive – they were also doing it to display their status and rank.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Status means the professional or social position of a person in relation to others. And rank is another way of saying the same thing. Do you think we still dress to impress, Alice – or are things a bit freer than they were in the 18 th Century? I'm a jeans and T-shirt man, as you know.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well yes, indeed, you don't have to be suited and booted for our job – and that means smartly dressed. But I think the way we dress is still important. But for women, particularly, I think we dress nicely for ourselves – not for anybody else. Sometimes I put on make-up – not because I'm going out – but because it makes me feel good.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: You always look nice – with or without make-up, Alice. Alice Thank you, Neil! That's very nice. But let's listen now to academic Philippa Dietrich from the University of the West of England, Bristol, talking about valuing ourselves for all our attributes – not just our appearance. INSERT Philippa Dietrich, University of the West of England, Bristol This focus just on appearance – on looks – really sends people the ideas that their bodies are just objects to be looked at. Having a belief system or focussing on your values in life or other attributes or personality characteristics or interests or anything else that's not to do with appearance is really important. Our bodies are not there to be looked that – they have functions. Neil What Philippa Dietrich said makes sense to me. We need to focus on our inner beauty. What do you think, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, I think you should stop posting selfies on social media then, Neil! Now here's the answer to today's quiz question. I asked: From a study done in the UK, which physical aspect of their appearance were men most likely to say was their favourite? Was it… a) their hair? b) their face? Or c) their height?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said a) hair.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: And you were wrong I'm afraid, Neil! It's c) height. A poll conducted by ComRes for BBC Radio found that when it comes to appearance, men were most likely to mention their height - 21% of them in fact said it was their favourite physical attribute whereas for women, 35% of them said their hair was their favourite thing.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, forget about my hair, Alice - I'm tall too, OK, so… you can tell us the words we heard today, please?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Here they are: get in shape overindulge New Year's resolution appearance genes corset garments status rank suited and booted

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Happy New Year everyone and we hope you keep your New Year's resolutions! Please join us again soon.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
